alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Chaves County Plains; Chuska Mountains; Curry County; De Baca County; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Eastern Lincoln County; Eastern San Miguel County; Espanola Valley; Estancia Valley; Far Northeast Highlands; Far Northwest Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Guadalupe County; Jemez Mountains; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass; Middle Rio Grande Valley, Albuquerque Metro Area; Northeast Highlands; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Northwest Highlands; Roosevelt County; San Francisco River Valley; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Santa Fe Metro Area; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Southwest Mountains; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Upper Tularosa Valley; West Central Mountains; West Central Plateau (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 31 at 3:44AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ..NEXT WINTER STORM TO BRING MOUNTAIN SNOW AND WIND FROM THURSDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY NIGHT... After several days of tranquil weather and relatively warm temperatures, notable changes are in store for Thursday night into Saturday night as a vigorous disturbance and associated cold front sweep east across the region. Good chances for precipitation begin Thursday evening across western New Mexico and spread eastward through the daytime hours on Friday. Snow levels will start off high...nearly 9000 feet...but crash to valley floors on Friday night into Saturday morning, though precipitation coverage also decreases during this time. A little snow may mix in late Friday night for the Albuquerque metro area, but no accumulation is expected, whereas a dusting is possible for Santa Fe. At the same time, precipitation is forecast to become more focused across the western and northern mountains, especially southern and western-facing slopes, where snow amounts may exceed one foot in the highest elevations of the Jemez mountains. Storm totals of 5 to 9 inches are likely for the Chuska, Sangre de Cristo, and portions of the Gila National Forest. Breezy to gusty winds on Friday strengthen further for Saturday and Saturday night, with noticeably colder conditions taking hold as well. West winds along and east of the central mountain chain may gust up to 55-60mph, especially south of Interstate 40. Winds will gradually begin to subside later Saturday night, but may remain gusty until around mid-day Sunday. Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest updates on this situation.
